revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Use American English|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Kelsey Grammer | image = Kelsey Grammer 2010 (cropped).jpg | caption = Grammer in May 2010 | birth_name = Allen Kelsey Grammer | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1955|2|21|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Charlotte Amalie, U.S. Virgin Islands|Charlotte Amalie]], [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|Saint Thomas]] | years_active = 1979–present | credits = {{unbulleted list|[[Frasier Crane]] in ''[[Cheers]]'' and ''[[Frasier]]''|[[Sideshow Bob]] in ''[[The Simpsons]]''|Blinkous Galadrigal in ''[[Trollhunters]]''}} | education = {{unbulleted list|[[Pine Crest School]]|[[Juilliard School]]}} | occupation = Actor, voice actor, comedian | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | spouse = {{unbulleted list|{{marriage|Doreen Alderman
|1982|1990|reason=divorced}}|{{marriage|Leigh-Anne Csuhany
|1992|1993|reason=[[Annulment|ann.]]}}|{{marriage|[[Camille Grammer|Camille Donatacci]]
|1997|2011|reason=divorced}}|{{marriage|Kayte Walsh
|2011}}}} | children = 7, including [[Spencer Grammer|Spencer]] and [[Greer Grammer]] }} '''Allen Kelsey Grammer''' (born February 21, 1955) is an American actor, voice actor and comedian, best known for his two-decade-long portrayal of psychiatrist Dr. [[Frasier Crane]] on the [[NBC]] sitcoms ''[[Cheers]]'' and ''[[Frasier]]''. He has won five [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s, three [[Golden Globe Awards]], and one [[Tony Award]], and has also worked as a television producer, director, writer, and as a voice actor on ''[[The Simpsons]]'' as [[Sideshow Bob]] (for which he received his fifth [[Primetime Emmy]]). He also recently won a [[Daytime Emmy Award]] for [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Performer in an Animated Program|Outstanding Performer in an Animated Program]] for his voice work in [[Guillermo del Toro]]'s award-winning series ''[[Trollhunters]]''.http://cdn.emmyonline.org/day_44th_winners_creative_v02.pdf Grammer has been married four times and has seven children. ==Early life== Grammer was born February 21, 1955, in [[Charlotte Amalie, U.S. Virgin Islands|Charlotte Amalie]], [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|Saint Thomas]], [[U.S. Virgin Islands]],{{cite web|url = http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/kelsey-grammer/160338/|title = Kelsey Grammer|publisher = [[CBS Corporation]]|accessdate = April 24, 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151218112747/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/kelsey-grammer/160338/|dead-url = no|archive-date = December 18, 2015|website = [[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]]}} the son of Sally (née Cranmer; 1928–2008),{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9807E4DB173AF932A25754C0A96E9C8B63 |title=Paid Notice: Deaths: Sally Grammer |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 11, 2008|archivedate= June 29, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629000402/http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9807E4DB173AF932A25754C0A96E9C8B63 | deadurl=no }}{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/nypost/access/69234977.html?dids=69234977:69234977&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT |work=[[New York Post]] |date=March 5, 2001 |title=Frasier on the Couch – Unusually Frank Profile of Kelsey Grammer and His Famous Demons |last=Buckman |first=Adam |quote=...St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands. Kelsey had been born on the island on Feb. 21, 1955 |archivedate=December 16, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216224226/https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/nypost/doc/333923952.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS%3AFT&type=current&date=&author=&pub=&edition=&startpage=&desc= |deadurl=no |df= }} a singer and actress, and Frank Allen Grammer, Jr. (d. 1968), a musician and owner of a [[coffeehouse|coffee shop]] and a bar and grill called Greer's Place.{{Cite web|title = SMOKE 3/00 - Kelsey Grammer|url = http://www.smokemag.com/0300/cover.htm|website = www.smokemag.com|access-date = 2016-02-20|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150906065614/http://www.smokemag.com/0300/cover.htm|dead-url = yes|archive-date = September 6, 2015|date = 2000|df = mdy-all}}{{cite web|url = http://www.ginnydougary.co.uk/a-suitable-case-for-treatment/|title = A Suitable Case for Treatment|work = GinnyDougary.com|authorlink = Ginny Dougary|first = Ginny|last = Dougary|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110720155916/http://www.ginnydougary.co.uk/2005/11/12/a-suitable-case-for-treatment/|archivedate=July 20, 2011 |deadurl = no|publisher = [[Irish Independent]]}}{{Cite web|title = Kelsey Grammer Biography (1955-)|url = http://www.filmreference.com/film/9/Kelsey-Grammer.html|website = filmreference.com|access-date = 2016-02-20|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151018161147/http://www.filmreference.com/film/9/Kelsey-Grammer.html|archive-date = October 18, 2015|dead-url = no}} He had one younger sister. Grammer was two years old when his parents divorced.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} Grammer and his sister Karen were subsequently raised by their mother and grandparents in [[New Jersey]].Kelsey Grammer, Desert Island Discs, BBC Radio 4 (Dec 2017) The family relocated to Florida, and shortly afterwards his grandfather died when Kelsey was twelve. Two years later, in 1968, Frank Allen Grammer, his father, was murdered.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/kelsey-grammers-tragic-family-life-2013-5|title=Kelsey Grammer's Tragic Family Life|last=|first=|date=|work=Business Insider|access-date=June 7, 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://gazettereview.com/2016/02/what-happened-kelsey-grammer-news-updates/|title=What Happened To Kelsey Grammer - New Updates for 2017|last=Stanton|first=Barry W.|date=February 23, 2016|work=The Gazette Review|access-date=June 7, 2017|language=}} Grammer attended [[Pine Crest School]], a private preparatory school in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]]. It was there that he first began to sing and perform on stage. From the age of 16, with his mother's approval, he began to smoke a pipe. Grammer won a scholarship to the prestigious [[Juilliard School]]. He was a member of [[List of Juilliard School people|Group 6]], 1973–1975.{{cite news | archive-date=January 26, 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110126015951/http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/2004/edition_11-28-2004/in_step_with_0 | author-link=James Brady (columnist) | url=http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/2004/edition_11-28-2004/in_step_with_0 | title=In Step With: Kelsey Grammer | work=[[Parade (magazine)|Parade Magazine]] | date=November 28, 2004 | last=Brady | first=James}} He failed to attend classes and was eventually expelled. == Career == === Stage === After leaving [[Juilliard School|Juilliard]], Grammer had a three-year internship with the [[Old Globe Theatre]] in [[San Diego]] in the late 1970s before a stint in 1980 at the [[Guthrie Theater]] in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. He made his Broadway debut in 1981 as "Lennox" in ''[[Macbeth]]'', taking [[Macbeth (character)|the lead role]] when [[Philip Anglim]] withdrew after receiving negative reviews. Grammer then played [[Michael Cassio]] in a Broadway revival of ''[[Othello]]'', with [[James Earl Jones]] and [[Christopher Plummer]]. In 1983 he performed in the demo of the [[Stephen Sondheim]]–[[James Lapine]] production ''[[Sunday in the Park with George]]'', starring [[Mandy Patinkin]]. In 2000, Grammer again played ''Macbeth'' on Broadway, in a production that closed after only 10 days.{{cite news | access-date=2016-02-20 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/20/theater/macbeth-will-close-after-just-10-days-on-broadway.html | title='Macbeth' Will Close After Just 10 Days on Broadway | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=2000-06-20 | last=Mckinley | first=Jesse | issn=0362-4331}} On April 18, 2010, Grammer made his [[Broadway musical]] debut playing the role of Georges in a revival of the [[Jerry Herman]]/[[Harvey Fierstein]] musical ''[[La Cage aux Folles (musical)|La Cage aux Folles]]'', for which he was nominated for a [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Musical]]. Grammer originated the roles of Charles Frohman and Captain Hook in the Broadway premiere of the musical ''[[Finding Neverland (musical)|Finding Neverland]]'' in March 2015, continuing with the roles through June 28, 2015.{{cite web | url = http://www.ibdb.com/Production/View/498337 | title= ''Finding Neverland'' | publisher= [[Internet Broadway Database]] ([[The Broadway League]]) | accessdate= October 12, 2015}} He returned to the stage from January 19 to April 3, 2016. Most recently he made an appearance in the West End production of ''[[Big Fish (musical)|Big Fish]]''.{{cite web | access-date=2016-02-22 | url=http://www.ibdb.com/Person/View/74304 | title=Kelsey Grammer | publisher=[[Internet Broadway Database]] ([[The Broadway League]])}} === Television === Grammer's television career began in the early 1980s when he portrayed [[Stephen Edward Smith|Stephen Smith]] in the [[NBC]] miniseries ''[[Kennedy (miniseries)|Kennedy]]''. ====''Cheers'', ''Frasier'', and ''Wings''==== Grammer came to broader public attention in 1984 as Dr. [[Frasier Crane]] in the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Cheers]]''. Grammer's former Juilliard classmate and Broadway co-star Patinkin suggested Grammer to the New York [[casting (performing arts)|casting director]], and he got what was supposed to be a six-episode job, but ended up as a regular cast member until May 1993, when the show ended.{{Cite web|url = https://movies.yahoo.com/person/kelsey-grammer/biography.html|title = Kelsey Grammer Biography|website = [[Yahoo! Movies]]|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121009230813/http://movies.yahoo.com/person/kelsey-grammer/biography.html|archive-date = October 9, 2012}} In September 1993 the character became the center of the spin-off ''[[Frasier]]'', one of the most successful spin-offs in TV history. In addition to starring, he also directed more than 30 episodes, especially during the second half of the series, and sang the closing theme "Tossed Salads and Scrambled Eggs." ''Frasier'' was nominated for and won many [[Frasier#Awards|awards]] during its 11-year run, concluding in May 2004. In 2001, he negotiated a US $700,000-per-episode salary for ''Frasier''. His 20-year run playing Dr. Frasier Crane ties a length set by [[James Arness]] in playing [[Matt Dillon (Gunsmoke)|Marshal Matt Dillon]] on ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' from 1955 to 1975 but was surpassed by [[Richard Belzer]] in playing [[John Munch|Det. John Munch]] on ''[[Homicide: Life on the Street]]'' and ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' since 1993. Frasier Crane also had a [[crossover (fiction)|crossover]] appearance in 1993 ''[[Wings (1990 TV series)|Wings]]'' episode "Planes, Trains, & Visiting Cranes". ====Post-''Frasier''==== In 2004, Grammer starred as [[Ebenezer Scrooge]] in the well-received [[television film|made-for-television]] [[film adaptation]] of the stage musical of [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[A Christmas Carol (musical)|A Christmas Carol]]''. In 2005, Grammer returned to television. He produced and appeared in an American adaptation of the [[Television in the United Kingdom|British show]] ''[[The Sketch Show]]'', which aired on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]. The main cast consisted of [[Malcolm Barrett (actor)|Malcolm Barrett]], [[Kaitlin Olson]], [[Mary Lynn Rajskub]] and [[Paul F. Tompkins]], as well as [[Lee Mack]] from the British version of the show. Grammer appeared in only short opening and closing segments in each episode. Many of the [[Sketch comedy|sketches]] from the British version were re-created, such as the "California Dreamin'", "English Course", and "Sign Language" sketches. Only six episodes of the show were made, and it was [[Cancellation (television)|canceled]] after only four of them had aired. In 2007, Grammer starred with [[Patricia Heaton]] in the American sitcom ''[[Back to You (TV series)|Back to You]]''. It was canceled by Fox after its first season. His next attempt, [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Hank (2009 TV series)|Hank]]'', fared even worse. It was canceled after only five episodes had aired. Grammer later commented, "Honestly, it just wasn't very funny."{{cite web|url = http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/hank-kelsey-grammer-canceled-sitcom|title = ''Hank'': Kelsey Grammer says He Scrapped the Cancelled Sitcom|date = December 7, 2009|last = Kimball|first = Trevor|archive-url = https://archive.is/20120716104754/http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/hank-kelsey-grammer-canceled-sitcom/|archive-date = 2012-07-16|dead-url = no|access-date = 2016-02-22|website = tvseriesfinale.com}} In 2011 and 2012, Grammer starred in the [[Starz (TV channel)|Starz]] drama series ''[[Boss (TV series)|Boss]]'' as a fictional mayor of Chicago in the mold of [[Richard J. Daley]] which premiered in October 2011.{{cite news | title=State to give boost to West Side film studio working on 'Boss' | work=[[Sun Times]] | date=May 10, 2011 | last=Roeder | first=David}} It was his first [[Dramatic programming|dramatic TV series]].{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/reviews/story/2011-10-20/boss-kelsey-grammer/50846360/1 | title=Kelsey Grammer rules on the unruly 'Boss' | work=[[USA Today]] | date=October 21, 2011 | last=Bianco | first=Robert}} At the [[69th Golden Globe Awards|2012 Golden Globe Awards]] Kelsey Grammer won the award for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama#2010s|Best Actor in a Television Series Drama]] for his role on ''[[Boss (TV series)|Boss]]''. The show ran for 18 episodes over two seasons.{{cite web|last = Andreeva|first = Nellie|title = 'Boss' Won't Return To Starz For Season 3, May Wrap Story With Two-Hour Movie|url = http://www.deadline.com/2012/11/boss-cancelled-starz-after-two-seasons/|accessdate = November 28, 2012|date = November 20, 2012|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150920110707/http://deadline.com/2012/11/boss-cancelled-starz-after-two-seasons-374943/|archive-date = 2015-09-20|dead-url = no|website = [[Deadline Hollywood]]}} Grammer played a villain in the [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]]'s [[Transformers movies]]' fourth installment, ''[[Transformers: Age of Extinction]]'', starring [[Mark Wahlberg]].{{cite news | archive-date=2016-02-22 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222004855/http://variety.com/2013/film/news/kelsey-grammer-to-play-villain-in-transformers-4-1200434753/ | dead-url=no | url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/kelsey-grammer-to-play-villain-in-transformers-4-1200434753/ | title=Kelsey Grammer to Play Villain in 'Transformers 4′ | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=May 1, 2013 | last=Kroll | first=Justin}} Grammer paired up with comedian/actor [[Martin Lawrence]] to star in the comedy ''[[Partners (2014 TV series)|Partners]]'' for [[Lionsgate Television|Lionsgate TV]]. The Lionsgate-produced show would be written and executive produced by [[Robert L. Boyett]] and Robert Horn, known for writing hit shows like ''[[Family Matters]]'', ''[[Living Single]]'', ''[[Full House]]'', ''[[Designing Women]]'', and ''[[Perfect Strangers (TV series)|Perfect Strangers]]''. ===Other appearances=== In addition to being producer, he guest-starred as the [[Death (personification)#Death (angels) in religion|Angel of Death]] on ''[[Medium (TV series)|Medium]]'', and Captain Morgan Bateson in the ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' episode "[[Cause and Effect (Star Trek: The Next Generation)|Cause and Effect]]". Grammer was also the featured guest on long running [[BBC Radio 4]] programme, [[Desert Island Discs]], in December 2017.{{cite web|title= Desert Island Discs|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09hp7cl|publisher=bbc.co.uk|accessdate=7 February 2018}} === Voice work === Grammer's well-known voice and [[Mid-Atlantic English|mid-Atlantic accent]] make him popular for [[voice acting|voiceover work]]. He has provided the voice of [[Sideshow Bob]] on ''[[The Simpsons]]'', winning an [[Emmy Award]] for his work in the episode "[[The Italian Bob]]", his fifth Emmy win.{{cite magazine |url = |title = It's Evening in America|last = |first = |date = May 2012|magazine = [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |page = 157}} He has appeared in eighteen episodes from the show's inception in 1989 through 2015's "[[Treehouse of Horror XXVI]]", in which his character finally succeeded in killing [[Bart Simpson]] in one segment ("Wanted: Dead, then Alive"). Grammer supplied the voices for "[[List of Toy Story characters#Stinky Pete the Prospector|Stinky Pete the Prospector]]" in 1999 Disney/Pixar film ''[[Toy Story 2]]'', Vladimir in the Fox animated movie ''[[Anastasia (1997 film)|Anastasia]]'', Rothbart in ''[[Barbie of Swan Lake]]'', Zozi the Bear in the subsequently produced sequel ''[[Bartok the Magnificent]]'', the title character in the short-lived animated series ''[[Gary the Rat]]'', and the villain, Dr. Ivan Krank, on '' [[Teacher's Pet (2004 film)|Disney's Teacher's Pet]].'' He provided the opening speech and piano in [[The Vandals]]' song "Phone Machine" from the album ''[[Fear of a Punk Planet (album)|Fear of a Punk Planet]]'', and sang a rewritten version of the "grinch" on an episode of ''[[Just Shoot Me!]]''. He was the voice of the mad scientist [[monkey]], Dr. Frankenollie, in the [[Mickey Mouse]] short ''[[Runaway Brain]]''. He was also the narrator of ''[[Mickey's Once Upon a Christmas|Mickey Mouse – Once Upon a Christmas]]''. Grammer's voice has been featured in many commercials. One of the earliest was a 1998 commercial for [[Honey Nut Cheerios]], where he played the voice of the wolf in [[Little Red Riding Hood]]. Since 2006, Grammer has provided the voice for television commercials advertising [[Hyundai]]. In 2008, Grammer reprised his role of Dr. Frasier Crane in a commercial for [[Dr Pepper]] (''Frasier'' and ''Cheers'' co-star [[Bebe Neuwirth]] also reprised her role as [[Lilith Sternin]] in the same commercial, albeit in voice only). In 2013, Grammer voiced the [[Tin Woodman]] in ''[[Legends of Oz: Dorothy's Return]]''. In 2016, Grammer narrated the opening video package for [[WrestleMania 32]] and he voiced the role of Hunter in ''[[Storks (film)|Storks]]''. === Production work === His production company, Grammnet Productions, produces the [[The CW Television Network|CW]] [[situation comedy|sitcoms]] ''[[Girlfriends (U.S. TV series)|Girlfriends]]'' and ''[[The Game (U.S. TV series)|The Game]]'' (now on [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]]), the [[NBC]] drama ''[[Medium (TV Series)|Medium]]'', and many other projects. === Other work === In 1996, he starred in the feature comedy ''[[Down Periscope]]''. Also, in the 1990s, he did several commercials for [[Snapper Inc.|Snapper]] Mowers. Additionally, his film work includes the role of Dr. Hank McCoy (also known as the [[Beast (comics)|Beast]]) in ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'' and he was the voice of [[Snowball (Animal Farm)|Snowball]] in the live-action [[Animal Farm (1999 film)|film adaptation]] of the [[George Orwell]] book ''[[Animal Farm]]''. Grammer co-starred in the movie ''[[Swing Vote (2008 film)|Swing Vote]]'', playing the Republican incumbent. He played General [[George S. Patton]] in ''[[An American Carol]]''. In 2010, he starred in ''The Kelsey Grammer Bill Zucker Comedy Hour''.{{Cite web|title=THE KELSEY GRAMMER BILL ZUCKER COMEDY HOUR (PART 1) |url=http://www.vimeo.com/10084536 |website=[[Vimeo]] |access-date=2016-02-22 |publisher=Lucky Finn Productions |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306225111/https://vimeo.com/10084536 |archivedate=March 6, 2016 |df= }} == Personal life == === Family === Grammer has been married four times and has seven children and one grandchild {{as of|2016|lc=y}}.{{Cite magazine|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/10/11/spencer-grammer-welcomes-son-emmett-emmanual/ |title=Kelsey Grammer Becomes Grandfather |date=October 11, 2011 |first=Sarah |last=Michaud |first2=Blaine |last2=Zuckerman |magazine=[[People (American magazine)|People]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64ieHACXA?url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/10/11/spencer-grammer-welcomes-son-emmett-emmanual/ |archivedate=January 15, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} His first marriage, to dance instructor Doreen Alderman, lasted from 1982 to 1990, although they were separated for the last six years of that period.{{cite magazine |url = http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20110754,00.html|title = Cheers and Tears|last = Lipton|first = Michael A.|date = July 5, 1993|magazine = [[People (magazine)|People]]|access-date = 2016-02-22|publisher = [[Time Inc.]]|issue = 1|volume = 40|last2 = Cunneff|first2 = Tom|first3 = Lorenzo|last3 = Benet|first4 = Bill|last4 = Steif|first5 = Bryan|last5 = Alexander|first6 = Vickie|last6 = Bane|last7 = Aunapu|first7 = Greg|page = 54}} They have one daughter, actress [[Spencer Grammer]] (born October 9, 1983).{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/spencer-grammer/270893 |title=Spencer Grammer |publisher=[[CBS Corporation]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64ieVkiv7?url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/spencer-grammer/270893 |archivedate=January 15, 2012 |accessdate=January 15, 2012 |deadurl=no |website=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]] |df= }} Through Spencer, Grammer has one grandson, Spencer's son Emmett Emmanual Hesketh (born October 10, 2011).{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Spencer-Grammer-Baby-1038613.aspx |title=Kelsey Grammer's Daughter Spencer Gives Birth to a Baby Boy |publisher=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]] |accessdate=January 15, 2012 |first=Natalie |last= Abrams |date=October 11, 2011}} After his divorce from Alderman, Grammer had a daughter, [[Greer Grammer|Kandace Greer Grammer]] ("Greer Grammer"; born February 15, 1992), with hair and makeup stylist Barrie Buckner. Greer was a cast member on [[MTV]]'s show ''[[Awkward.]]''{{cite web |url = http://www.hellomagazine.com/profiles/kelsey-grammer/|title = Kelsey Grammer|publisher = Hello Ltd|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150905102213/http://us.hellomagazine.com/profiles/kelsey-grammer/|archivedate = 2015-09-05|accessdate = January 15, 2012|dead-url = no|website = [[Hello!|HelloMagazine.com]]}}{{IMDb name|id=3408254|name=Greer Grammer|accessdate=November 29, 2012}} His second marriage, to former [[striptease|exotic dancer]] Leigh-Anne Csuhany in September 1992,{{cite magazine |url = http://www.ew.com/article/1992/11/06/kelsey-grammer|title = Scenes From Two Marriages|date = November 6, 1992|publisher = [[Time Inc.]]|last = Appelo|first = Tim|magazine = [[Entertainment Weekly]]}} lasted one year. Grammer filed for an [[annulment]] when Csuhany was three months pregnant and evicted her from their home. The pregnancy ended in a miscarriage. Grammer claimed she was [[domestic violence|abusive]] and fired a gun at him.{{cite episode | author-link2=William Shatner | first1=Kelsey (Guest) | last1=Grammer | last2=Shatner | first2=William (Host) | network=[[The Biography Channel]] | season=1 | number=5 | series-link=Shatner's Raw Nerve | title=Kelsey Grammer | series=Shatner's Raw Nerve | airdate=16 December 2008}} In 1994, he met 28-year-old Tammi Baliszewski, also known as Tammi Alexander, at a bar in [[Manhattan Beach, California]]. In December 1994, they appeared together on the cover of [[People (American magazine)|''People'' magazine]], announcing their engagement and Grammer's substance abuse problems.{{cite magazine |url = http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20104584,00.html|title = Grammer Tested|last = Gliatto|first = Tom|date = December 5, 1994|magazine = [[People (magazine)|People]]|access-date = 2016-02-22|publisher = [[Time Inc.]]|issue = 23|volume = 42|last2 = Tomashoff|first2 = Craig|last3 = Matsumoto|first3 = Nancy|page = 94}} In August 1997, Grammer married his third wife, former ''[[Playboy]]'' model [[Camille Donatacci]]. They met on a [[wikt:blind date|blind date]] in 1996.{{cite web|url = http://www.eonline.com/news/another_kid_kelsey/48147|date = August 30, 2004|first = Bridget|last = Byrne|publisher = [[NBCUniversal]]|title = Another Kid For Kelsey|accessdate = November 25, 2006|website = [[E!#E! Online|E! Online]]}} They have a daughter, born October 2001, and a son, born August 2004, both born to a [[surrogacy|surrogate mother]]. During their marriage, several of Grammer and Donatacci's homes were featured in magazines, including ones in [[Malibu, California]] (February 2001, ''[[InStyle]]''), [[Maui]] (May 2004, ''InStyle''), [[Long Island|Long Island, New York]] (April 2008, ''InStyle''), Bachelor Gulch, [[Colorado]] (''[[Architectural Digest]])'',{{cite web|title = Far from Frasier: Camille and Kelsey Grammer keep things loose in Colorado|url = http://www.architecturaldigest.com/celebrity-homes/2004/kelsey-grammer-colorado-retreat-article|publisher = [[Condé Nast]]|date = June 2004|accessdate = November 28, 2012|last = Frank|first = Michael|website = [[Architectural Digest]]}} and [[Bel Air, Los Angeles]] (''Architectural Digest''). It was announced on July 1, 2010, that Donatacci had filed for divorce, citing irreconcilable differences.{{cite web|url = http://www.tvguide.com/News/Kelsey-Grammer-Divorce-1020130.aspx|title = Kelsey Grammer's Wife Files For Divorce|website = [[TVGuide]].com|publisher = [[CBS Corporation|CBS]]|last = Eng|first = Joyce|date = Jul 1, 2010|access-date = 2016-02-22}} Grammer and Donatacci's divorce was finalized on February 10, 2011.{{Cite web|title = Judge grants Kelsey Grammer divorce in LA|url = http://apnews.excite.com/article/20110210/D9LA33NO2.html|website = [[Excite|Excite News]]|access-date = 2016-02-22|date = Feb 10, 2009|publisher = [[Excite|Excite Network]]|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141027155520/http://apnews.excite.com/article/20110210/D9LA33NO2.html|archive-date = 2014-10-27|dead-url = no}} On August 12, 2010, Grammer announced that he was going to be a father for the fifth time with girlfriend Kayte Walsh, a British flight attendant 25 years his junior, daughter of retired soccer player [[Alan Walsh (footballer)|Alan Walsh]].{{Cite news|url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2010/08/kelsey-grammer-to-be-a-dad-again/1|title = Kelsey Grammer To Be a Dad Again|work = [[USA Today]]|first = Ann|last = Oldenburg|date = August 12, 2010|accessdate = January 15, 2012|publisher = [[Gannett Company]]}} However, in October, Grammer announced that Walsh had miscarried six weeks earlier.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20433294,00.html |title=Kelsey Grammer's Girlfriend Has a Miscarriage |first=Mike |last=Fleeman |first2=Elizabeth |last2=Leonard |date=October 9, 2010 |accessdate=January 15, 2012 |magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910210218/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C20433294%2C00.html |dead-url=no |archive-date=September 10, 2015 |df= }} The couple announced their engagement in December 2010,{{cite web|title=Kelsey Grammer: Yes, I'm Getting Married – Because I'm in Love |date=December 28, 2010 |work=[[People (American magazine)|People]] |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20453525,00.html |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |access-date=2016-02-22 |last=Leonard |first=Elizabeth |last2=Hammel |first2=Sara |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908211023/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C20453525%2C00.html |archive-date=September 8, 2015 |dead-url=no |df= }} and married at [[The Plaza Hotel]] in New York City on February 25, 2011, two weeks after the finalization of Grammer's third divorce.{{cite web|work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |title=Kelsey Grammer Is a Married Man – Again |date=February 25, 2011 |first=Ulricha |last=Wihlborg |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20469135,00.html |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |access-date=2016-02-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150622212041/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C20469135%2C00.html |archive-date=June 22, 2015 |dead-url=no |df= }} Grammer and Walsh have a daughter, born July 2012,{{cite web|title = Kelsey Grammer Welcomes Daughter Faith Evangeline Elisa|url = http://celebritybabies.people.com/2012/07/13/boss-kelsey-grammer-welcomes-daughter-faith-evangeline-elisa/|publisher = [[Time Inc.]]|accessdate = July 13, 2012|website = [[People (magazine)|People]]|last = Michaud|first = Sarah|date = July 13, 2012|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150907201147/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2012/07/13/boss-kelsey-grammer-welcomes-daughter-faith-evangeline-elisa/|archive-date = 2015-09-07|dead-url = no}} and two sons, born July 2014{{cite news|last1 = Leon|first1 = Anya|title = Kelsey Grammer Welcomes Son Kelsey Gabriel Elias|url = http://celebritybabies.people.com/2014/07/24/kelsey-grammer-welcomes-son-kelsey-gabriel-elias/|accessdate = July 24, 2014|publisher = [[Time Inc.]]|date = July 24, 2014|work = [[People (magazine)|People]]|last2 = Leonard|first2 = Elizabeth|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150906043749/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2014/07/24/kelsey-grammer-welcomes-son-kelsey-gabriel-elias/|archive-date = 2015-09-06|dead-url = no}} and November 2016. ====Murder of Karen Grammer==== On July 1, 1975, Grammer's younger sister, 18-year-old Karen Grammer, was abducted, raped, and murdered by [[Freddie Glenn]], Michael Corbett, and one other man. Grammer, then 20, identified her body. He and his sister had been close, and he was devastated by her death; his later bouts of alcoholism and drug addiction were fueled in part by guilt and depression.{{cite web|url = http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2015/04/kelsey-grammer-sister-death-finding-neverland|work = [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date = May 2015|title = Out to Lunch with Kelsey Grammer|first = John|last = Heilpern|accessdate = April 24, 2015|archivedate = April 21, 2015|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150421001356/http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2015/04/kelsey-grammer-sister-death-finding-neverland|deadurl = no|publisher = [[Condé Nast]]}} In an interview with [[Oprah Winfrey]], Grammer stated he could consider forgiving the men involved if they would at least take responsibility for the crime, but that they all continued to say they were innocent. In the same interview, Grammer expressed his loss of faith for a few years after Karen's death.{{cite episode | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LT6Sf4Ek4b8 | title=Kelsey Grammer | series=Oprah's Next Chapter | network=[[Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel)|Oprah Winfrey Network]] | airdate=26 August 2012 | author-link1=Oprah Winfrey | first1=Oprah | last1=Winfrey | season=2 | series-link=Oprah's Next Chapter | number=3}} He subsequently forgave Glenn, but refused to support his release, saying it would "be a betrayal of my sister's life." He named his daughter [[Spencer Grammer|Spencer Karen Grammer]] in part for his sister. === Lawsuits === In 1995, Grammer was accused of [[statutory rape]] of his child's babysitter, who was 15 at the time, but a grand jury did not indict him due to there being no physical evidence, only tapes of voicemail messages.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/25/nyregion/a-grand-jury-refuses-to-indict-frasier-star-on-a-sex-charge.html|title=A Grand Jury Refuses to Indict 'Frasier' Star on a Sex Charge|publisher=The New York Times|date=February 25, 1995|accessdate=July 25, 2018|}} The same year, he was sued by ex-girlfriend Cerlette Lamme for [[defamation]] of character and [[privacy law|invasion of privacy]] over content he included in his autobiography ''So Far''.{{cite web|url = http://www.cosmicbaseball.com/grammer9.html|title = Kelsey Grammer 1999 Cosmic Player Plate|publisher = Cosmicbaseball.com|accessdate = December 19, 2009}} In September 1996, he crashed his [[Dodge Viper]] while intoxicated, and subsequently checked into the [[Betty Ford Center]] (an [[Drug rehabilitation|alcohol rehabilitation]] clinic) for 30 days. In 1998, Grammer filed a lawsuit against [[Seth Warshavsky|Internet Entertainment Group]] (IEG), which Grammer claimed had stolen from his home a [[celebrity sex tape|videotape]] of him having sex with a woman. IEG countersued Grammer, denying it was in possession of such a tape, and Grammer's suit was eventually dropped.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,614966,00.html |title=Report: Kelsey's 'X'-Files |website=[[People (magazine)|People]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |date=June 7, 1999 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402160641/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C614966%2C00.html |archive-date=April 2, 2015 |dead-url=no |df= }} IEG President [[Seth Warshavsky]] later said, "We have been presented with another Kelsey Grammer tape. But we have no plans to air it. We are still evaluating it at this time."{{cite web|url = http://www.eonline.com/news/37400/kelsey-grammer-sex-tape-suit-unsealed|title = Kelsey Grammer Sex Tape Suit Unsealed|publisher = [[NBCUniversal]]|first = Daniel|last = Frankel|date = December 3, 1998|archivedate = April 24, 2015|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150424040942/http://www.eonline.com/news/37400/kelsey-grammer-sex-tape-suit-unsealed|deadurl = no|website = [[E!|E! Online]]}} Grammer later reflected,
Whether or not you're a celebrity—even if you're just an old slob with a video camera—you don't realize you shouldn't do it. So you throw the tape in the back of a dark closet until your old girlfriend remembers it's there because you're famous now and she's not. But if you're not prepared to do the time, don't do the crime.{{cite web|url = http://www.maximonline.com/articles/index.aspx?a_id=7159|title = The Beast Unleashed!|work = [[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]|accessdate = December 19, 2009|archivedate = December 24, 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081224050430/http://www.maxim.com/articles/index.aspx?a_id=7159|publisher = [[Biglari Holdings]]}}
In August 2008, [[Freedom's Watch|Bradley Blakeman]], a former aide to [[George W. Bush]], filed a copyright lawsuit in federal court on [[Long Island]] over Grammer's movie ''[[Swing Vote (2008 film)|Swing Vote]]'', claiming that parts of its plot and marketing had been stolen from him. The lawsuit claimed that Blakeman had given a copyrighted screenplay called ''Go November'' to Grammer in 2006, and that Grammer agreed to develop the project and star as a Republican president but instead ended up playing a similar role in ''Swing Vote'', which was released on August 1, 2008. Grammer's spokesman dismissed the claims as "[[frivolous litigation|frivolous]]" and a "waste of time". The lawsuit was settled in 2010 for $10.{{cite web|first=Keith|last=Staskiewicz|url=http://ew.com/article/2010/03/30/kelsey-grammer-settles-lawsuit-for-only-10/|title=Kelsey Grammer settles lawsuit for only $10|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=March 30, 2010|accessdate=February 5, 2018}} === Drug abuse issues === Grammer has a history as a frequent [[alcoholism|abuser of alcohol]]. In 1988, Grammer was arrested for [[driving under the influence|drunk driving]] and [[cocaine]] possession and sentenced to 30 days in jail.{{cite web|url = http://www.tribute.ca/people/Kelsey+Grammer/3430/17850|title = Kelsey Grammer bio: An American Carol Actor|publisher = Tribute Entertainment Media Group|accessdate = December 19, 2009|website = [[Tribute (magazine)|Tribute]]|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140221204321/http://www.tribute.ca/people/kelsey-grammer/3430/17850/|dead-url = no|archive-date = 2014-02-21}} In August 1990, Grammer was arrested again for cocaine possession and was sentenced to three years' [[probation]], fined $500, and required to perform 300 hours of [[community service]]. In January 1991, Grammer was given an additional two years' probation for violating his original probation through additional cocaine use. The cast and producers of both ''Frasier'' and ''Cheers'' held [[intervention (counseling)|interventions]] to attempt to help him. Grammer's personal problems affected his work; co-star [[Bebe Neuwirth]] and writer [[Ken Levine (TV personality)|Ken Levine]] cited delays with rehearsals and filming due to his erratic behavior. Writer [[Dan O'Shannon]] recalled, however, that{{cite news |url = https://www.gq.com/entertainment/movies-and-tv/201210/cheers-oral-history-extended?printable=true|title = The Best TV Show That's Ever Been|work = [[GQ]]|date = October 2012|accessdate = September 27, 2012|author = Raftery, Brian|publisher = [[Advance Publications]]}} {{quote|He would ooze into the studio, his life all out of sorts. Jimmy would say "Action," and he would snap into Frasier and expound in this very erudite dialogue and be pitch-perfect. And Jimmy would yell "Cut!" and he would ooze back into Kelsey—glazed-over eyes, half asleep, going through whatever he was going through. It was the most amazing transformation I'd ever seen.{{r|gqraftery201210}}}} Grammer credits his religion for helping him through with his struggles with alcohol and drug abuse, as well as his personal tragedies.{{cite interview |interviewer=[[Larry King]] |title=Larry King Live: The Unsinkable Kelsey Grammer |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0103/16/lkl.00.html |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=March 16, 2001 |access-date=February 28, 2017}} === Health problems === On May 31, 2008, while [[paddleboarding]] with his then-wife [[Camille Grammer|Camille]] in Hawaii, Grammer experienced a heart attack.{{cite web |url = http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20203756,00.html|title = Kelsey Grammer Suffers Mild Heart Attack|publisher = [[Time Inc.]]|date = June 2, 2008|accessdate = June 10, 2008|website = [[People (magazine)|People]]|last = Fleeman|first = Mike}} He was discharged on June 4, 2008, and was said to be "resting comfortably" at his Hawaiian residence.[http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b141124_kelsey_grammer_of_hospital.html Kelsey Grammer Out of the Hospital] from ''[[E! Online]]'' {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801053417/http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b141124_kelsey_grammer_of_hospital.html |date=August 1, 2008 }} Seven weeks after the attack, Grammer told ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' that, although at the time his spokesman described the attack as mild, it was in fact more severe, almost leading to his death, as his heart had stopped.{{Cite web|title = Actor Kelsey Grammer nearly died after heart attack|url = http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-34651320080724|website = [[Reuters|Reuters India]]|access-date = 2016-02-23|language = en-IN|publisher = [[Thomson Reuters]]|last = Galbraith|first = Robert|date = July 24, 2008}} Grammer thought Fox's decision to cancel his TV sitcom ''[[Back to You (TV series)|Back to You]]'' contributed to his health problems, stating that "It was a very stressful time for me, and a surprise that it was cancelled. But you know, everything that doesn't kill us—which it almost did—makes us stronger!"{{cite web|url = http://www.exposay.com/kelsey-grammar-says-failed-sitcom-caused-his-heart-attack/v/21803|title = Kelsey Grammer Says "Failed Sitcom" Caused His Heart Attack|accessdate = November 28, 2012|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131102061644/http://www.exposay.com/kelsey-grammar-says-failed-sitcom-caused-his-heart-attack/v/21803|archive-date = 2013-11-02|date = July 24, 2008|website = Exposay.com}} On June 28, 2008, Grammer checked into an undisclosed [[Manhattan]] hospital after complaints of feeling faint. Other reports said Grammer was hospitalized for an irregular heartbeat.{{cite news|title = Kelsey Grammer in Hospital With Irregular Heartbeat|url = http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/28/kelsey-grammer-in-hospital-with-irregular-heartbeat/?_r=1|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|date = July 28, 2008|publisher = [[Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr.]]|issn = 0362-4331}} His publicist said that it may have been due to a reaction to medication.{{cite web|url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/08/05/kelsey-grammer-returns-home-after-brief-hospital-visit|title = Kelsey Grammer Returns Home After Brief Hospital Visit|work = [[Fox News]]|date = August 5, 2008|publisher = [[21st Century Fox]]}}{{cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/08/05/kelsey-grammer-out-of-hos_n_117129.html|title = Kelsey Grammer Out of Hospital After 2nd Stay|work = [[Huffington Post]]|location = USA|date = August 5, 2008|publisher = [[Verizon Communications]]}} === Political views === [[File:Kelsey Grammer fleet week.jpg|upright|thumb|Grammer during [[Fleet Week]] in New York City, in May 2006]] Grammer is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and has expressed an interest in someday running for [[United States Congress]].{{Cite web|title = Transcript: Twenty Years of 'Frasier'|url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,98169,00.html|website = [[Fox News]]|date = September 24, 2003|access-date = 2016-02-23|language = en-US|publisher = [[21st Century Fox]]}} He has also expressed an interest in running for Mayor of New York,{{cite web|url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/kelsey-grammer-emmys-snub-republican-boss-frasier-362744|title = Kelsey Grammer Accuses Emmys of Snubbing Him Because He's a Republican|work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date = August 15, 2012|publisher = [[Prometheus Global Media]]|first = Jordan|last = Zakarin|access-date = 2016-02-23}} and for the U.S. Presidency.{{cite news |last=Dinneen |first=Steve |title=Kelsey Grammer Interview |date=9 June 2016 |website=CityAM |url=http://www.cityam.com/242955/kelsey-grammer-interview-the-frasier-and-breaking-the-bank-star-talks-about-donald-trumps-hair-running-for-president-and-jared-leto-being-a-clown}} Grammer was a guest at President [[George W. Bush]]'s first inauguration.{{Cite web|title = Ladies and Gentlemen, Your Next Republican President|url = http://nymag.com/arts/theater/features/64948/|website = [[New York (magazine)#Digital expansion and blogs|NYMag.com]]|access-date = 2016-02-23|date = March 21, 2010|last = Sternbergh|first = Adam|publisher = New York Media, LLC}} Grammer endorsed [[Rudy Giuliani]] in the [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|2008 presidential primary]] and later campaigned for [[John McCain]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|general election]].{{Cite web|title = Kelsey Grammer's federal campaign contribution|url = http://www.newsmeat.com/fec/bystate_detail.php?st=CA&last=Grammer&first=Kelsey|access-date = 2016-02-23|website = NEWSMEAT|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131006094707/http://www.newsmeat.com/fec/bystate_detail.php?st=CA&last=Grammer&first=Kelsey|archive-date = 2013-10-06}}{{cite news|url = http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/elections/political-emissaries-descend-valley|title = Political emissaries descend on valley: Richardson, Grammer rally voters at events|publisher = News + Media Capital Group LLC|date = October 11, 2008|accessdate = October 16, 2008|issn = 1097-1645|work = [[Las vegas review journal|Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|first = Richard|last = Lake}} Grammer promoted [[RightNetwork]], a [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] start-up American television network.{{cite news|url = http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2010/04/19/2010-04-19_fox_too_liberal_for_you_kelsey_grammer_backs_upstart_rightwing_tv_network.html|title = Fox too liberal for you? Kelsey Grammer backs upstart right-wing TV network, RightNetwork|location = New York|work = [[New York Daily News|Daily News]]|first = Richard|last = Huff|date = April 19, 2010|publisher = [[Mortimer Zuckerman]]}} He endorsed [[Michele Bachmann]] for the [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|Republican nomination]] for president in 2012.{{cite web|url = http://www.frumforum.com/celebrity-endorsements-draw-attention-not-votes|title = Endorsements Draw Attention, Not Votes|date = June 26, 2011|accessdate = August 31, 2011|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150403081854/http://www.frumforum.com/celebrity-endorsements-draw-attention-not-votes/|archive-date = 2015-04-03|website = FrumForum|last = Berenson|first = Tessa}} After [[Mitt Romney]] won the nomination, Grammer endorsed him.{{cite web |url = http://thehill.com/video/campaign/202579-kelsey-grammer-says-mitt-romney-would-probably-do-a-pretty-good-job|title = Kelsey Grammer says Mitt Romney would 'probably do a pretty good job'|accessdate = June 4, 2012|website = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date = January 5, 2012|last = Kurtz|first = Judy|publisher = Adam Prather}} He supported [[Ben Carson]]'s candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination in 2016, although he endorsed [[Donald Trump]] when the latter was selected. Grammer supported the [[Tea Party movement]] on economic issues such as [[small government]] and [[Income tax|lower taxes]]. He does not support the traditional Republican platform on social issues such as [[same-sex marriage]], stating "I think marriage is up to two people who love each other".{{cite web |url=http://piersmorgan.blogs.cnn.com/2011/10/12/kelsey-grammers-tea-party-support-i-think-smaller-government-is-a-good-idea/ |title= Kelsey Grammer's tea party support: 'I think smaller government is a good idea' |author= |date=October 12, 2011 |website=[[Piers Morgan Live]] |publisher=[[CNN]] |access-date=February 27, 2017}} While a ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine profile published in 2010 described him as [[pro-choice]],{{cite news |last=Stenbergh |first=Adam |date=March 21, 2010 |title=Ladies and Gentlemen, Your Next Republican President |url=http://nymag.com/arts/theater/features/64948/ |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |location=New York |access-date=March 3, 2017 |quote=Grammer is not only Republican; he's [...] pro-choice ('but I don't advocate for abortion') [...].}} Grammer in 2015 posted an [[Instagram]] photo of himself with his wife Kayte wearing a T-shirt by the [[pro-life]] group Abort73.{{cite news |last=Sieczkoswki |first=Caren |date=October 9, 2015 |title=Kelsey Grammer Wears Bizarre Anti-Choice Shirt |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/kelsey-grammar-anti-abortion-shirt_us_5617c5aee4b0e66ad4c75d8a |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |access-date=March 3, 2017}} ''[[City A.M.]]'' described Grammer as "one of Hollywood's best-known Republicans, a rare spark of red in a blue sea of [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]]". == Awards == {{main|List of awards and nominations received by Kelsey Grammer}} Grammer won a number of [[Emmy Award|Emmys]], [[Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Award]], and [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globes]] for his work on ''Frasier''. He was the first American actor ever to be nominated for multiple Emmy awards for portraying the same character on three different television shows (''[[Cheers]]'', ''[[Frasier]]'', and ''[[Wings (1990 TV series)|Wings]]''). Grammer has received at least 45 nominations for major awards and has won on 18 occasions.{{IMDb name|1288|section=awards}} He has received 14 individual [[Emmy Award]] nominations for four different television shows (plus an additional two as part of the ''Frasier'' ensemble) and has won five times. At the [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globes]], he has received nine nominations and three times been victorious. He has received two [[People's Choice Awards]], and in 1999 his directorial skills were recognized with a nomination for a [[Directors Guild of America]] award for directing an episode of ''Frasier''. He received a [[Saturn Award]] nomination for [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]] for his role in ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]''. On May 22, 2001, he was presented with a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] for television. On April 20, 2009, Grammer was presented the inaugural Television chairman's Award at the annual [[NAB Show]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]].{{cite news|url = https://variety.com/article/VR1118002504.html?categoryid=3597&cs=1|title = NAB launches Chairman's Award|publisher = [[Penske Media Corporation]]|first = Susan|last = Young|date = April 16, 2009|work = [[Daily Variety]]|issn = 0042-2738}} In 2010, Grammer enjoyed his first Tony Award nomination for ''[[La Cage aux Folles (musical)|La Cage Aux Folles]]'' as Best Leading Actor in a Musical. In 2016, he received his second Tony Award nomination for ''[[The Color Purple (musical)|The Color Purple]]'' as Best Revival of a Musical{{cite web|url=http://www.tonyawards.com/en_US/nominees/shows/201509271443403544657.html|title=The Tony Award Nominees - Shows|website=TonyAwards.com}} and won the award. ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" !Year !Title !Role !Notes |- |1992 |''Galaxies Are Colliding'' |Peter | |- |1995 |''[[Runaway Brain]]'' |Dr. Frankenollie |Voice
